question_data.question: What is the importance of studying parasitic infections?
choices: To understand their impact on host health
To develop effective treatments and prevention methods
To understand their environmental and economic impacts

question_data.question: Based on the contextual deep-dive into the category of parasites covered in slide 2, identify two major differences between bacteria and helminths?
question_data.correct_answer: Bacteria are microscopic and unicellular organisms, while helminths are multicellular worms visible to the naked eye. Bacteria can reproduce on their own, while helminths lay eggs in the host's body to reproduce
question_data.explanation: Bacteria are single-celled organisms that can live almost anywhere - in soil, the ocean, even inside humans and other animals. They can reproduce on their own through cellular division. On the other hand, Helminths are larger, multicellular organisms, often referred to as worms. They cannot multiply inside humans and are often visible to the naked eye. They typically lay eggs inside the body of the host which then get excreted and ingested by another host to continue their lifecycle.
